title: Why don't Americans honor Amerigo Vespucci? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, for starters, we named our country after him, both it’s official name — the United States of America — and its demonym, American. On top of that, the entire Western Hemisphere is named after Mr. Vespucci. That’s an area of about 17 million square miles that includes close to a billion people. While there are countries named after historical people, no person in the entirety of human history has two continents named after him! Why isn’t Amerigo Vespucci well known, better studied, and more honored in the U.S.? Chiefly because the fact that the country and the two continents are named after him are almost accidental. In 1502, Vespucci, a Florentine sailing for Portugal, set out a few years after Columbus to explore the lands Columbus didn’t reach. Vespucci made one very noteworthy discovery: While Columbus believed to his dying day that the lands he visited were an extension of Asia, Vespucci determined that they were a wholly separate landmass, and a completely different continent. A few years after Vespucci returned from his voyage, German cartographer Martin Waldseemuller created a map of the New World, and named it America, after the Latin version of Vespucci’s first name. And the name stuck. It’s worth noting that we Americans didn’t name our country. It was named by a German cartographer, after an Italian explorer sailing for the Portuguese king. And it was named close to 200 years before our country was even founded.
